raw_text:
Ink helps drive democracy in Asia
 
 The Kyrgyz Republic, a small, mountainous state of the former Soviet republic, is using invisible ink and ultraviolet readers in the country's elections as part of a drive to prevent multiple voting.
 
 This new technology is causing both worries and guarded optimism among different sectors of the population. In an effort to live up to its reputation in the 1990s as "an island of democracy", the Kyrgyz President, Askar Akaev, pushed through the law requiring the use of ink during the upcoming Parliamentary and Presidential elections. The US government agreed to fund all expenses associated with this decision.
 
 The Kyrgyz Republic is seen by many experts as backsliding from the high point it reached in the mid-1990s with a hastily pushed through referendum in 2003, reducing the legislative branch to one chamber with 75 deputies. The use of ink is only one part of a general effort to show commitment towards more open elections - the German Embassy, the Soros Foundation and the Kyrgyz government have all contributed to purchase transparent ballot boxes.
 
 The actual technology behind the ink is not that complicated. The ink is sprayed on a person's left thumb. It dries and is not visible under normal light.
 
 However, the presence of ultraviolet light (of the kind used to verify money) causes the ink to glow with a neon yellow light. At the entrance to each polling station, one election official will scan voter's fingers with UV lamp before allowing them to enter, and every voter will have his/her left thumb sprayed with ink before receiving the ballot. If the ink shows under the UV light the voter will not be allowed to enter the polling station. Likewise, any voter who refuses to be inked will not receive the ballot. These elections are assuming even greater significance because of two large factors - the upcoming parliamentary elections are a prelude to a potentially regime changing presidential election in the Autumn as well as the echo of recent elections in other former Soviet Republics, notably Ukraine and Georgia. The use of ink has been controversial - especially among groups perceived to be pro-government.
 
 Widely circulated articles compared the use of ink to the rural practice of marking sheep - a still common metaphor in this primarily agricultural society.
 
 The author of one such article began a petition drive against the use of the ink. The greatest part of the opposition to ink has often been sheer ignorance. Local newspapers have carried stories that the ink is harmful, radioactive or even that the ultraviolet readers may cause health problems. Others, such as the aggressively middle of the road, Coalition of Non-governmental Organizations, have lauded the move as an important step forward. This type of ink has been used in many elections in the world, in countries as varied as Serbia, South Africa, Indonesia and Turkey. The other common type of ink in elections is indelible visible ink - but as the elections in Afghanistan showed, improper use of this type of ink can cause additional problems. The use of "invisible" ink is not without its own problems. In most elections, numerous rumors have spread about it.
 
 In Serbia, for example, both Christian and Islamic leaders assured their populations that its use was not contrary to religion. Other rumours are associated with how to remove the ink - various soft drinks, solvents and cleaning products are put forward. However, in reality, the ink is very effective at getting under the cuticle of the thumb and difficult to wash off. The ink stays on the finger for at least 72 hours and for up to a week. The use of ink and readers by itself is not a panacea for election ills. The passage of the inking law is, nevertheless, a clear step forward towards free and fair elections." The country's widely watched parliamentary elections are scheduled for 27 February.
 
 David Mikosz works for the IFES, an international, non-profit organisation that supports the building of democratic societies.
llama3.2:1b: The Kyrgyz Republic is using invisible ink and ultraviolet readers in its upcoming presidential election as part of a drive to prevent multiple voting.
The law requiring the use of ink was pushed through by President Askar Akaev after a US government agreement was reached to fund expenses associated with it.
The technology behind the ink is simple: a small amount is sprayed onto the thumb and then dried, while ultraviolet light causes the ink to glow under normal light.
The use of ink has been met with both concern and guarded optimism in Kyrgyz society.
Some groups have expressed opposition due to concerns about safety, but others see it as an important step towards building democratic institutions.
The US government's funding of the law is seen as a commitment to free and fair elections.
Despite controversy over the safety of the ink, the parliamentary election on February 27 will proceed using this technology.
Experts say that while it may have limitations, the use of invisible ink is not a panacea for election problems.
llama3.2:3b: The Kyrgyz Republic is using invisible ink and ultraviolet readers in its upcoming Parliamentary and Presidential elections to prevent multiple voting.
The technology, funded by the US government, causes the ink to glow under UV light, making it visible for verification purposes only.

Despite controversy and misinformation among some groups, the use of ink has been praised as an important step forward towards free and fair elections, with similar technologies used in other countries such as Serbia and South Africa.
gemma2:2b: The Kyrgyz Republic is using invisible ink and UV readers to prevent multiple voting in upcoming elections.
The technology is controversial but intended to improve election fairness, particularly in a context where previous reforms have led to political instability.
This initiative aims to bolster the country's reputation for democracy after its legislative structure was significantly altered following a referendum in 2003.
Experts see this as a positive step towards increased transparency and a fair electoral process.
Concerns about the ink's effects on health and potential misinformation are circulating.
Despite these issues, some view the ink technology as a crucial tool for combating voter fraud.
The move is seen by many as significant progress, particularly considering recent election trends in neighboring former Soviet Republics.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Kyrgyz Republic uses ink in its upcoming elections to prevent multiple voting while US government funds all expenses associated with this decision.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Kyrgyz Republic introduces ink-based voter ID system as part of its effort to combat multiple voting during upcoming parliamentary and presidential elections, with mixed reactions from experts, government officials, and civil society groups.
The technology uses invisible ink sprayed on voters' left thumbs under UV light for identification purposes.
While the move aims to promote transparency, it has sparked controversy over concerns about potential health risks and misinformation spread by certain sectors.
The system, while controversial, is seen as a significant step towards improving election integrity in the region.
qwen2.5:3b: The Kyrgyz Republic uses invisible ink with ultraviolet readers to prevent multiple voting in upcoming elections.
This follows a push by President Askar Akaev to re-establish its reputation as an island of democracy after reducing legislative power in 2003.
While this technology is seen as a commitment towards open elections, it has faced criticism from some groups including those perceived to be pro-government.
The debate often centers around concerns about the ink's potential harm and how to remove it properly.
Despite these challenges, the use of invisible ink represents progress towards fairer elections in the country.
Parliamentary elections are scheduled for 27 February, with presidential elections taking place later in the Autumn.

The use of the ink is only one part of a larger effort to ensure more transparent elections, with contributions from various organizations including the US government, German embassy, and Soros Foundation.

stablelm2:1.6b: The Kyrgyz Republic uses invisible ink and ultraviolet readers to prevent multiple voting during its upcoming Parliamentary and Presidential elections as part of a broader effort to promote more open elections.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The Kyrgyz Republic, a small, mountainous country formerly part of the Soviet Union, is implementing invisible ink and UV readers in its elections to combat multiple voting and ensure more transparent processes.
This innovative technology, funded by the US government, aims to strengthen democracy following concerns about the nation's decline from a "democratic island" status in the mid-1990s.
Voters have their left thumbs sprayed with ink that glows neon yellow under UV light; only those without ink or who refuse to be inked can enter polling stations and vote.
While generally well-received, this method has sparked controversy, primarily among pro-government groups, due to misconceptions about its safety and potential health impacts.
Despite these concerns, experts view the ink as a crucial step towards fair elections, particularly given the upcoming parliamentary and presidential polls in February 2023.
This initiative is part of a broader effort to improve transparency, following lessons from recent elections in Ukraine and Georgia.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Kyrgyz Republic is implementing invisible ink and ultraviolet readers in elections to prevent multiple voting, aiming to uphold democratic integrity.
President Askar Akaev pushed for this measure, funded by the US government, as part of broader efforts to ensure fair elections, including the use of transparent ballot boxes.
The ink, sprayed on voters' thumbs, is visible only under UV light and prevents repeat voting.
While some support the move as a step toward transparency, others, particularly pro-government groups, criticize it, comparing it to marking livestock.
Misinformation about the ink's safety has also fueled opposition.
Similar ink has been used in elections worldwide, though concerns and rumors about its removal persist.

Despite its limitations, the inking law represents progress toward free and fair elections, with the upcoming parliamentary elections seen as a precursor to a potentially transformative presidential election.
